Rationale
The development of short supply chain is becoming a topic of growing interest among consumers, researchers and public bodies in Europe. More than ever, the resilience of a territory relies in the capacity of becoming less dependant of outlier productors (reference?), which is an element identified by the pandemic conditions.

However, the evaluation of pertinent sustainable indicators for this short supply networks is one the major topic of discussion in the scientific and practitioners communities. The problem relies in the selection of these ‚Äòpertinent‚Äô sustainable indicators and trade-offs that need to be considered for a holistic evaluation and the scope of the short supply chain. Moreover, depending of the material or product and their technological process associated to, this entakes difficulties in terms of dependance of stakeholders beyond the scope of the short circuit.

The context of this research is the development of a short plastic recycling network for distributing recycling purposes (Santander et al. 2020). The development of the development of distributing recycling approach via additive manufacturing (DRAM) (Cruz Sanchez et al. 2020) is emerging as an interesting topic to foster the use of certains plastic waste materials in order to extend eventually (multiple) lifecycle for a printed product. More precisely, the use of recycled assets in the printing process chain of additive manufacturing technology can give add value to wastes to create possible final products or even scientific equipement (Pearce 2020) a a lower cost than the commercial. In a sense, this approach could be an operationalization strategy for the development of secondary raw materials, which is one of major pillars in the recycling strategy for the Circular economy in Europe, even if this intervention remains largely case-dependent.

Nevertheless, there remain a gap in the scientific literature to define in what sense DRAM could be considered as sustainable transition in the global aspect of the term. The challenges of sustainable development today are generally seen in terms that go beyond just meeting basic human needs to embrace a broader vision of sustainability as fairness: enhancing human well-being to more equitably meet the needs of both current and future generations. Clark and Harley (2020) developed an integrative framework for sustainability considering five major pilards: (1) environment and development, (2) governance, (3) complexity, and (4) context dependence.
At the core of research on sustainability are the intertwined nature‚Äìsociety interactions. Sustainability science research has focused on the four key elements involved in those interactions:
Goals (what people want from sustainable development),
Resources (the capital assets of the Anthropocene System, which may be natural or anthropogenic), - Actors (communities, firms, states and other entities with agency that strive to use resources to achieve their goals),
Institutions (rules, norms, culture, beliefs that shape the behavior of actors).
These key elements are bound together through key relationships of consumption and production, mediated by the relative power of different actor groups to affect one another‚Äôs actions and beliefs.
Therefore, contextualizing thi sustainable concptual framework to the DRAM context, the main research question is for this project are:
How to evaluate the global sustainability of short supply chains to foster the plastic recycling networks in a local territory?.
2.What are the ‚Äòpertinent‚Äô qualitative and quantitative indicators to evaluate the local distributed recycling network in terms of revelance of quality and feasibility to obtain appropriate data with local stakeholders?
One element to highlight is the impact that third-spaces such as innovations labs, fablabs and/or makerspace can play, having a role of agents of change in the development of this recycling practices (Roux-Marchand et al. 2020).
The objectives of this research are:
Establish a grid of economical, political, environemental and social indicators.
Define model of stakeholders that can be impacted (positive / negative) for the case of plastic recycling
‚Ä¶
Therefore, the purpose of this research is to set a baseline of sustainable indicators to evaluate a local short supply chain network for distributed recycling.
Based on the results of these indicators, the main challguen will be the articulation and means of implementation / evaluations to build decision tools for this type of networks.

Rationale
A new paradigm of plastic recycling, called distributed plastic recycling, has emerged in the literature in order to face the socio-environmental challenges related to plastic waste management. Under this new model of small recycling centers, the main hipohesis relies on the fact that a distributed and local spaces can provide recycled feedstock to transform it into finish (or prototypes) for a local community. To do so, the use of additive manufacturing enables the technical paths.
However, as with any recycling system, its feasibility must be evaluated before its implementation. Although research has been conducted regarding the technical feasibility of distributed plastic recycling, little is known about its feasibility from the supply chain point of view (CruzSanchez2020?). .content-box-yellow[From a supply chain perspective, the establishment of recycling networks‚Ä¶ ]
This study intends to explore the local impact derived from the implementation of a distributed plastic recycling chain in a territory.
The purpose of this research is to explore and assess the local impact derived from the implementation of a distributed plastic recycling chain. The study intends to research which and how the ecosystem services are impacted due to the implementation of the plastic recycling chain proposed. While not all types of materials can be recycled given the technical difficulties, the estimation of the environmental advantage is needed to assess at early stages the pertinence of ths distributed approaches
This study seeks to address the following questions:
What are the appropriate ecosystem service indicators for assessing distributed plastic recycling?
How does the implementation of a distributed plastic recycling chain impact on ecosystem services?
What are the barriers and drivers for the development of a distributed plastic recycling chain in a territory?

Rationale
Some ideas:
On Circular Economy (CE)
Circular economy decisions are very complex but often the perceptions, attitudes, and personal values of decision makers directly influence organizations‚Äô strategic actions towards a circular economy. Both active participation of organizations and the role of decision makers are pivotal to implement a circular economy for plastics (Khan et al. 2020).
Identifying and assessing specific barriers associated with the workplace context could be crucial for achieving better employee engagement and a lower ecological footprint for organizations (Yuriev et al. 2020)
Barriers of CE implementation
Khan et al. (2020) identified barriers to deploy CE Plastics in order of importance are as follows. The foremost barrier is that organizations (Entreprises) do not have easy access to recycling facilities. Second, organizations cannot transport plastic waste to recycling facilities. Third, organizations do not have enough space to store plastic waste. Fourth, organizations do not have enough time to sort plastic waste. Fifth, organizations do not have sufficient funds to pursue plastic recycling. Sixth, organizations do not have skilled personnel to sort plastic waste. Seventh, organizations do not have an environmental expert at the management level. Lastly, organizations do not know about potential buyers of plastic waste. These findings imply that prominent barriers are physical factors rather than knowledge. Overall, these findings contribute to the literature on the barriers of a circular economy
On Theory of planned Behaviour
Ajzen (1991) developed Theory of Planned Behaviour (TPB) which is one of the most influencing model for designing behavioral interventions (Yuriev et al. 2020). Therefore, researchers have been increasingly employing the TPB model across various disciplines including environmental science and sustainability management TPB postulates considers three main aspects
Attitude towards behavioral intention,
Subjective Norms (SN), and
Perceived Behavioral Control (PCB),
together they shape behavioral intention as well as actual behavior. To date, TPB has received around 90,000 citations (Yuriev et al. 2020)

Theory of planned behavior (TPB) is based on the assumption that some conscious reasoning is involved in the formation of intentions to perform a behavior.
Behavior partly on the control of the individual
Behavior is predicted by attitudinal and normative factors and perceived behavioral control (PBC).
PBC reflects the extent to which the individual feels able to perform the behavior.
Past behavior tends to predict intentions and future behavior
The factors that influenced the past behavior continue to influence the intentions and future behavior, but past behavior does not cause future behavior.

Definition


Definition.recycling


Attitude


Attitude toward the behavior and refers to the degree to which a person has a favorable or unfavorable evaluation or appraisal of the behavior in question


The extent to which plastic recycling is valued by people, whether positive or negative


Subjective Norms


The perceived social pressure to perform or not to perform the behavior


The extent to which people are influenced by perceived norms of plastic recycling in their surroundings


Perceived Behavioral Control (PCB)


The perceived ease or difficulty of performing the behavior and it is assumed to reflect past experience as well as anticipated impediments and obstacles


the perceived power (and knowledge) of people to implement plastic recycling

They are indications of how hard people are willing to try, of how much of an effort they are planning to exert, in order to perform the behavior


A perceived likelihood or subjective probability of decision makers that they will implement plastic recycling in their organizations


Behaviour




The extent to which organizations have implemented best practices of plastic recycling


On Distributed Recycling via Additive Manufacturing
The centralized schemes is the current paradigm for recycling concerns large majority of research on recycling behaviour comes within the scope of municipal waste management schemes.
Centralized recycling schemes have been criticized for inducing much waste transportation, which limits the ecological and economic benefits of recycling, especially in low density areas. Therefore, in order to mitigate CO2 emissions and financial costs of transporting, the concept of distributed recycling emerged. Distributed recycling schemes are characterized by decentralized plastic waste collection, sorting and transformation. It includes in-house recycling, or recycling in local small-scale recycling networks, be it in a community, a company, or a public organisation. If understandings of distributed recycling regarding the decentralisation level differs, scholars agree on its potential for reducing gas emissions from waste collection and creating groundbreaking alternative value chains to the established raw-resources based manufacturing .
For Kreiger (2014), distributed recycling schemes could bring benefits in any economic context, independently of development levels. In the present study, the technology enabling recycling in a distributed recycling scheme is 3D printing, which we call distributed recycling via additive manufacturing (DRAM). A large variety of goods can be produced recycling plastic with 3D technology. Therefore, we believe DRAM has the potential for enhancing the circular economy approach and ‚Äúclose the loop.‚Äù
On pro-environmental behaviours
Yuriev et al. (2020) identified nine systematic literature reviews on pro-environmental behaviors (Li et al., 2019; Lo et al., 2012; Koop et al., 2019; Staddon et al., 2016; Varotto and Spagnolli, 2017; Inoue and Alfaro-Barrantes, 2015; Francoeur et al., 2019; Norton et al., 2015; Yuriev et al., 2018). These are the only existing systematic literature reviews from the last 10 years that covered various individual environmental actions. Having

Positionnement strat√©gique du projet
Dans un contexte de consommation mondiale croissante et de pression accrue sur les ressources, qui plus est, celles d√©di√©es √† la survie de l‚Äôesp√®ce humaine, il est urgent de dissocier la croissance √©conomique de l‚Äôutilisation de ces derni√®res. Ceci pourrait notamment permettre d‚Äôaccro√Ætre la r√©sistance de l‚ÄôEurope aux incertitudes li√©es √† l‚Äôapprovisionnement en mati√®res premi√®res et √† la s√©curit√© des cha√Ænes de valeur, comme c‚Äôest le cas actuellement avec la crise sanitaire (Sany√©-Mengual et al., 2019).
Il est donc temps de rendre nos fili√®res industrielles plus r√©silientes et adapt√©es aux nouvelles conditions impos√©es par la plan√®te. Pour soutenir une transition industrielle, dont celle vers une bio√©conomie r√©pondant au concept d‚Äô√©conomie circulaire, ce projet cherche √† d√©velopper une m√©thodologie permettant d‚Äô√©valuer les services √©cosyst√©miques, et donc les externalit√©s des organisations industrielles √©mergentes. Par la mise en commun de comp√©tences du ICD/CREIDD1 et de l‚ÄôERPI2, cette m√©thodologie, bas√©e sur un couplage analyse du cycle de vie et mod√©lisation par dynamique de syst√®mes, cherche √† faciliter l‚Äô√©valuation d‚Äôun projet industriel d√®s sa phase amont en consid√©rant ses potentiels impacts positifs et/ou n√©gatifs sur son territoire. L‚Äôapproche propos√©e sera test√©e sur le cas du recyclage, l‚Äôun des piliers de l‚Äô√©conomie circulaire, et en particulier sur la mise en place d‚Äôun d√©monstrateur de type ¬´ smart-grid du recyclage ¬ª du plastique en circuit court. Ce projet permet √©galement de soutenir les acteurs publics et priv√©s par le d√©veloppement d‚Äôoutils d‚Äôaide √† la d√©cision support√©s par les technologies num√©riques tel que d√©fini dans l‚Äôaxe efficacit√© √©nerg√©tique de l‚Äôannexe 1 du texte d‚Äôappel √† projet.

Contenu scientifique
Le concept d‚Äô√©conomie circulaire (EC) est un √©l√©ment central pour promouvoir un mod√®le durable, r√©g√©n√©rateur et inclusif qui peut aider de mani√®re significative nos √©conomies √† se r√©concilier avec les limites et les fronti√®res de notre plan√®te en restaurant les syst√®mes naturels, en r√©duisant les √©missions de GES (gaz √† effet de serre), et en minimisant la perte de capital naturel et de biodiversit√©. Le fonctionnement en circuit court est l‚Äôun des piliers pour rendre les op√©rations d‚Äôune fili√®re plus efficaces et rationnelles, tout en cr√©ant de la valeur locale (Capasso et al., 2019). Cependant son op√©rationnalisation n√©cessite des prises de d√©cision qui s‚Äôav√®rent difficiles, car elles challengent le paradigme actuel des activit√©s industrielles, centr√©es principalement sur l‚Äô√©valuation technico-√©conomiques et, encore trop peu et trop r√©cemment sur des consid√©rations environnementales. En effet, la vision traditionnelle reste pr√©gnante bien que limit√©e car elle ne consid√®re pas syst√©matiquement l‚Äôensemble des impacts d‚Äôune activit√© sur les √©cosyst√®mes.
Comme d√©montr√© par les travaux r√©alis√©s depuis 2001 par le CREIDD sur les th√©matiques de l‚Äô√©cologie industrielle, l‚Äô√©co-conception, l‚Äôanalyse de cycle de vie et l‚Äô√©valuation des risques environnementaux, la compr√©hension des m√©canismes de transition industrielle en incluant des dimensions de durabilit√©, sont fondamentaux. De m√™me, ils ont montr√© l‚Äôimportance d‚Äôune vision int√©gr√©e pour la conception des syst√®mes industriels-territoires (Bruel et al., 2019, 2016, 2014; Troussier et al., 2017; Vadoudi et al., 2015, 2014). Plus r√©cemment, des travaux ont montr√© que le rapprochement de l‚Äô√©cologie industrielle et de l‚Äô√©conomie √©cologique peut √™tre un moyen d‚Äôaller au-del√† de l‚Äô√©tude physique des flux de mati√®re et d‚Äô√©nergie (Bruel et al., 2016). En particulier dans ce projet on s‚Äôint√©ressera √† la quantification et prise en compte des services rendus par une organisation industrielle √† son territoire (espace naturel, humain et social). Ceci soul√®ve la question des externalit√©s environnementales et plus particuli√®rement des services √©cosyst√©miques rendus.
Les services √©cosyst√©miques ont √©t√© d√©finis par (De Groot et al., 2002) comme la capacit√© des processus et des constituants de la nature √† fournir des biens et services qui r√©pondent aux besoins humains, directement ou indirectement. Ces biens et services sont g√©n√©ralement associ√©s √† des fonctions de r√©gulation, des fonctions d‚Äôhabitat, des fonctions de production et des fonctions d‚Äôinformation. Plus pr√©cis√©ment, dans le domaine de l‚Äôenvironnement, les externalit√©s n√©gatives constituent des situations de pollutions, d‚Äôalt√©ration des ressources naturelles, de destruction de paysages, de pertes de biodiversit√© et d‚Äôautres nuisances environnementales qui affectent le bien-√™tre d‚Äôindividus sans que cette perte ne soit compens√©e par un m√©canisme marchand. La plupart du temps, les externalit√©s environnementales sont des co√ªts additionnels pris en charge par les autorit√©s publiques (ex : gouvernement, collectivit√©s territoriales) et les citoyens. Elles se mat√©rialisent notamment par la pollution atmosph√©rique, les nuisances sonores, les √©missions de gaz √† effet de serre, la pollution des eaux et des sols, mais √©galement par les atteintes √† la biodiversit√©.
Des √©tudes soulignent que les d√©cideurs, les d√©veloppeurs de produits, les dirigeants d‚Äôentreprises, les administrateurs publics ou les consommateurs prendraient des d√©cisions diff√©rentes s‚Äôils avaient l‚Äôinformation leur permettant d‚Äô√©valuer plus largement les cons√©quences environnementales de leurs d√©cisions (Bithas, 2011; Hond, 2000; O‚ÄôRourke et al., 1996; Van den Bergh, 2012) ou s‚Äôils devaient √©galement payer les prix refl√©tant la valeur mon√©taire des externalit√©s de l‚Äôutilisation des mati√®res et de l‚Äô√©nergie. Elles concluent aussi que, fondamentalement, les probl√®mes environnementaux sont caus√©s par les d√©faillances de la r√©glementation et du march√© qui peuvent √™tre corrig√©es si les d√©cideurs ont la bonne information et s‚Äôils sont expos√©s aux bons prix.
De plus, les changements environnementaux sont li√©s √† des effets de deux natures: leviers indirects et pressions directes. Par leviers indirects, le Millenium Ecosystem Assessment (MEA) (Assessment, 2005) adresse les changements d√©mographiques, √©conomiques, sociopolitiques, scientifiques et technologiques. Quant aux pressions directes, elles incluent la conversion des sols, la surexploitation des ressources naturelles, l‚Äôapport excessif de nutriments, les maladies, les invasions d‚Äôesp√®ces et le changement climatique. Ces pressions affectent les √©cosyst√®mes de diff√©rentes mani√®res selon les contextes et agissent √† travers diff√©rentes √©chelles organisationnelles, temporelles et spatiales. Les syst√®mes industriels sont fortement impliqu√©s et responsables des pressions qu‚Äôils exercent sur la biodiversit√© et les services √©cosyst√©miques. Le MEA a identifi√© six d√©fis majeurs concernant directement les impacts des activit√©s industrielles :la raret√© de l‚Äôeau douce, le changement climatique, les changements d‚Äôhabitat, les esp√®ces invasives, la surexploitation des oc√©ans et la surcharge de nutriments. Ces derniers peuvent conduire √† des d√©pendances qui varient en fonction des secteurs d‚Äôactivit√©s et au sein m√™me d‚Äôun m√™me secteur, selon la technologie employ√©e et du contexte de l‚Äôactivit√© de production ou de consommation *.
